From U.K. There is an aspect to all this that it often forgotten. Patriots were a branch of the English Whig Party who were opposed in Parliament by the Tory Party. This conflict between Patriot and Tory spread to the colonies. My home town of Rotherham Yorkshire was Patriot Whig. On a hill overlooking the town still stands a monument to the Boston Tea Party called Boston Castle. It was paid for by local politician and soldier the Earl of Effingham. At the end of the conflict a victory arch was built a few miles north at Parlington Hall. The names of British politicians and soldiers who fought on the American side are remembered today in the names of counties in Georgia and elsewhere. American Tories who fought on the British side get a mention now and again, but Patriot Brits nothing.

This was the prime reason for the American Revolution war. The Currency Act 0f 1764.Tea? Stamps? Gtfoh! It was a tax on colonial scrip, our paper money which lend to widespread poverty.

“That is simple. In the Colonies, we issue our own paper money. It is called ‘Colonial Scrip.’ We issue it in proper proportion to make the goods and pass easily from the producers to the consumers. In this manner, creating ourselves our own paper money, we control its purchasing power and we have no interest to pay to anyone.”  - Benjamin Franklin

“The colonies would gladly have borne the little tax on tea and other matters, had it not been that England took away from the colonies their money, which created great unemployment and dissatisfaction. Within a year, the poor houses were filled. The hungry and homeless walked the streets everywhere. The inability of the colonists to get power to issue their own money permanently out of the hands of George III and the International Bankers was the Prime reason for the Revolutionary War.” - Benjamin Franklin

Huh?  John, are you aware that John Adams later in life called his "disinterested defense" of the accused British soldiers the greatest service he ever did his country?  (He included his Presidency in that summation, btw.)  By representing the British soldiers - which no other lawyer in town could do without fear of getting their house burned down by John's cousin Sam (yes THAT Sam Adams)'s gang of ruffians - John was able to demonstrate to nervous, prosperous middle-colony landowners that it was British overreach, and not lawless Massachusettes radicalism, that was the real threat to be paying attention to.  If John had allowed the British soldiers to be railroaded, the middle colonies might have been more willing to see the unrest in Massachusettes as what the crown was calling it - an anarchistic mob bent on destroying the King's peace.

It was a war of ideas and propaganda, and John's defense of the British was a masterstroke in helping the young patriot cause attract members of all walks of society.

As a Brit visiting Boston MA, and listening to a party of nine year old kids visiting the ship in the harbor, I had to bite my tongue as I heard their teacher saying how outrageous this was of King George.  

Poor George II. A constitutional monarch, he was devoid of much personal responsibility for decisions in government, though of course he had great knowledge and influence, just as Elizabeth II does today.

"No taxation without representation" was the cry, because the colonists were Brits living outside of Britain, paying British taxes but having no representation in the British parliament. 

Wind forward about 200 years. Americans are taxed on their worldwide income, even if they live & work overseas.  They must file for federal taxes, and they weren't allowed an absentee ballot until .....1986. 

Call me cynical, but isn't this a case of the kettle calling the pot black?

The Colonists didn't want to be told where to buy tea!
